key_points: Residents of Waverly are preparing for additional rain from Tropical Storm Ida.
Melissa "Kay" Anderson and other locals are still recovering from recent flooding that damaged homes and killed 20.
Hurricane Ida has been downgraded to a tropical storm but is expected to bring 2 to 5 inches of rain to the area.
National Weather Service meteorologist John Cohen predicts Ida will weaken into a depression but still bring significant rain.
Waverly is under a flash flood watch, with continuous rain expected for 24 hours starting late Monday.
Residents are emotionally and physically preparing for the impact of the rain on their recovering homes and town.
Over 800 truckloads of debris have been cleared by volunteer agencies, the National Guard, and the Tennessee Department of Transportation.
The town's Emergency Management Agency is working to prevent creek blockage to avoid further flooding.
Waverly Police Department is monitoring the situation and prepared for possible evacuations, though none are expected.
Residents are encouraged to cover their homes and belongings with tarps available at a local staging area.
spokespersons: Grey Collier (Spokesperson, Humphreys County Emergency Management Agency)
